message_1: Consider a space X that can be triangulated with 10 tetrahedra. If we subdivide each tetrahedron into 4 smaller tetrahedra, how many tetrahedra are in the resulting triangulation of X?
message_2: If we subdivide each of the 10 tetrahedra into 4 smaller tetrahedra, we will have 10 * 4 = 40 tetrahedra in the resulting triangulation of X.
